item.title: Notion as a cms
item.description: try to make pull request to gatsby-source-notion-api improve my own plugin (and change name) I love Notion. Maybe a little too much. Enough…
item.content:encoded:
• try to make pull request to gatsby-source-notion-api
  • improve my own plugin (and change name)

I love Notion. Maybe a little too much. Enough to use it as the backend for my blog.

I have a database with all of my blog posts, and I just need to set the status to Published and the Date.

Why thought?

Well, first of all because I love Notion.

Secondly, you don’t need to pay for a hosting site, you can host it for free on netlify or github pages for example.

Gatsby is a static site generator, so it fetches from notion api’s at build time.

Create a database

Create a database. You could use my template so no configuration is needed. (link to Notion template)

Add integration on Notion

Follow this [link to notion integration]

Fetch gastby starter blog

gatsby new gatsby-site https://gatsby.com/gatsby-starter-blog

Download my notion starter blog

yarn add @ovalb/gatsby-source-notion-api
```Don't forget to ⭐  it. (it's a fork from gatsby-source-notion-api, since the maintainer hasn't supported it for a while)




#### Configure the source-notion-api plugin
Add you **secret_key**, and **api_key**

(probably use .env variables, don't commit them)




#### Enjoy
Write an article, publish it and then run

```bash
yarn run develop
```Enjoy! 



**Note**: there are still many issues with this system, and if you're looking for something that just works, Wordpress might be a better solution (or gatsby with any other proper CMS).



Check out my blog source code [link to github blog code]

item.title: The ultimate learning model: The fear of comfort is the beginning of mastery
item.description: change title LEGENDA The problem The solution What the learning model is Some example The problem Having read tons of learning and…
item.content:encoded:
change title

LEGENDA

  • The problem

  • The solution

    • What the learning model is

  • Some example

The problem

Having read tons of learning and productivity related books, I’ve somehow ended up being even more confused about what the best way to learn something really is.

(describe succintly and smartly my struggle and confusion)

[ feynman technique, deliberate practice, practice by doing, spaced repetition, …etc ]

The solution

I propose to you a mental framework, that helped me make sense of it all and I use every time I have to learn something.

(explain better what this actually means, maybe with some examples

(maybe make a graph)

what about deliberate practice and other learning concepts? (maybe make a visual graph of where or how these concepts integrate with my theory)

in depth examples? → link to other articles, subject specific.

================================================================

item.title: How I'm able to learn 30+ words a day
item.description: After a few months learning German, I quickly realised that one of the biggest bottlenecks for my comprehension, was the seemingly…
item.content:encoded:
After a few months learning German, I quickly realised that one of the biggest bottlenecks for my comprehension, was the seemingly insurmountable amount of words that I had to acquire.

If you’ve read any amount of material on learning and memorisation, you’re probably familiar with the concept of the forgetting curve. In short, try to review your words at increasing intervals of time to consolidate the information in the long term memory.

[add image of forgetting curve]

Oftentimes reality is more nuanced: I’ve found that I can look at some words once and remember them forever while some other seem not to stick no matter how many times I review them.

What if I could learn any word instantly on first try? (or second, let’s not be too cocky)

Before telling you my conclusion, I’d like to shed light on the experiments that led me to it and my thought process all along.

  • think about how I’m gonna set up my experiment, and how I’m gonna show data

Experiment 1: create as many links as possible

After a quick google search, I’ve found several lists of sound principles of memorisation.

The following are the ones that resonated the most with me and that I could implement.

  • Understand the information you’re learning
  • Link it to something you already know
  • Link it to another related word
  • Link it to a memorable visual image

I don’t see memory as either short term or long term, but as one single bucket, where the strength of the connection of a piece of information to the brain, will determine it’s longevity in memory.

(todo: Create an visual model of the brain as some sort of web or something, that allows visualize what an information really is)

  • Link words between each other

e.g. Koffer → Sarg → Gepäcks

  • Something you could do → link words that are similar to each other

e.g. lief = ran, liefern = to deliver

  • Another method → try to tie the first thing that comes to mind, to the actual meaning of the word

e.g. Tüte reminded me of sweatpants (italian tuta), but in german means bag, so I tried to associate it with a bag made of the same materia

item.title: Autoincrement with Notion API
item.description: If you’ve ever used Notion as a tracker of any kind, you’ve probably been annoyed by the fact that there is no way to prepopulate a database…
item.content:encoded:
If you’ve ever used Notion as a tracker of any kind, you’ve probably been annoyed by the fact that there is no way to prepopulate a database in any way.

More specifically, for my habit tracker, I’ve needed to manually create each entry and each time specify the current date.

Why do it every day, when you could do it once a year with one command? Thus, here’s a small CLI utility to generate Notion entries in a database with subsequent dates.

Setup

  • Create an integration from the Notion website
  • Go to your database page in Notion and click Share to give privilege to your newly created integration
  • Clone the repository
$ gh repo clone ovalb/notion-autoincrement
  • Create a file called .env in the just cloned folder and add:
    • Your NOTION_TOKEN received at the creation of your Integration
    • Your DATABASE_ID . Here’s how to find it.

Run the script and enjoy.

$ node main.js -365 #number of entries to create

Feel free to modify, steal or contribute to this script. With ❤️

item.title: Post di prova
item.description: Heading 2 When she reached the first hills of the Italic Mountains, she had a last view back on the skyline of her hometown Bookmarksgrove…
item.content:encoded:
Heading 2

When she reached the first hills of the Italic Mountains, she had a last view back on the skyline of her hometown Bookmarksgrove, the headline of Alphabet Village and the subline of her own road, the Line Lane. Pityful a rhetoric question ran over her cheek, then she continued her way. On her way she met a copy.

But nothing the copy said could convince her and so it didn’t take long until a few insidious Copy Writers ambushed her, made her drunk with Longe and Parole and dragged her into their agency, where they abused her for their projects again and again. And if she hasn’t been rewritten, then they are still using her.

heading 3

Altro paragrafetto un po’ piu’ lungo e formattato per esempio _questo e’ in italics, _questo e’ sottolineato, questo e’ bold.

CODICE

#include<stdio.h>
int main() {
	printf("Hello world")
	return 0
}

Altro linguaggio:

echo "go away!"

Todo list

  • Fare una cosa
  • Farne un’altra
  • La terzah

Unordered list

  • Uova

  • Pane

  • Acqua

    • Naturale
    • Gassata

  • Patatine

Ordered list

  1. Step

  2. Algorithm

  3. Dynamic

  4. Static

  5. Another stuff
